newsitem.title: USA: Orange County, Calif., CFO develops debt plan.
newsitem.headline: Orange County, Calif., CFO develops debt plan.

text.p: Orange County's chief financial officer on Friday said he developed a plan to reduce the California county's debt levels to "build trust" on Wall Street in the wake of its bankruptcy.
County CFO Gary Burton said his so-called Credit and Debt Management Strategy calls for the defeasance and refinancing of county bonds, and for the county to build up its budget reserves.
"We're trying to build trust with Wall Street, Main Street and Sacramento," Burton said in an interview. "We want everybody to know we're on the right track."
Burton said he hoped to bring his credit and debt management strategy before the county's Board of Supervisors in April. He said he expected the board to approve the plan.
Under Burton's plan, the county would build up its year-end balances, using a portion of the excess funds to defease or retire bonds before maturity.

Burton said the county should be able to build up a $140 million fund balance by fiscal 2001-2002. Those funds could be used to retire county bonds. The county could also defease bonds gradually, between now and 2002, Burton said.
By refinancing its 1995 Teeter bonds, Burton said the county would free up reserves and could save about $5 million annually in the coming years.

Burton said his program could reduce county debt per capita to $482 from $572. General obligation and lease debt as a percentage of assessed valuation would drop to 0.70 percent from 0.85 percent, he said.

Even so, Burton said total general obligation and lease debt service as a percentage of governmental fund expenditures would increase to 5.2 percent from 2.4 percent because of deferred debt-service payments.
Burton said his program could help the county attain single-A debt ratings and allow it to gain easier access to the capital markets with short- and long-term financings.
"We know we defaulted at one time, but everyone has been made whole," Burton said. "We're back on track with a financial plan to bring the debt levels down and hopefully get our credit ratings back."
"We have to get the bankruptcy behind us," he added.
Orange County filed for bankruptcy in December 1994 after sustaining losses of more than $1.6 billion on risky investments. It emerged from bankruptcy last June.
